title: Behind the lens on Sept. 11
text:
Thomas E. Franklin explains capturing the iconic photo 'Raising the Flag at Ground Zero.' | Photos by John Wheeler, Thomas E. Franklin Behind the lens on Sept. 11

On the evening of Sept. 11, Thomas E. Franklin, shaken from a day of photographing the World Trade Center attacks and trying to get back to New Jersey to finish his job, didn’t know he was carrying a piece of history in his digital camera.

For the veteran photographer, the photo that would become “Raising the Flag at Ground Zero” and get short-listed for the Pulitzer Prize was one of more than a thousand he took — all important, all capturing a snippet of time.

Story Continued Below

A photographer and videographer for the northern New Jersey newspaper The Record, Franklin was preparing for a meeting in his office in Hackensack, N.J., when a colleague told him about the first plane.

“I ran over to the window. I had a clear view across Jersey. I could see a huge gaping hole in the tower. I immediately took off for the city, but the tunnels and bridges were closed,” Franklin explained to POLITICO.

Having photographed the towers from New Jersey before, he headed to the riverfront in Jersey City.

Boats were going back and forth between New Jersey and Manhattan, and a triage center had been set up where Franklin was taking photos. He went back to the office to download photos and returned to Jersey City under the assumption that photographers had been asked to leave. “Because I had left, I was able to blend in with the crowd. I saw a photographer friend [John Wheeler] who said, ‘I know the head of the Jersey police department, let’s see if he can help us get on a boat,’” recalled Franklin.

The officer helped the two men get a ride over on a tugboat. “I never got his name,” said the photographer, “but it was a pivotal moment. I got the access I needed. A lot of the day is a blur, but being on the boat, I remember preparing myself for what I was going to see and had to remind myself that I had to focus on the job.”

In the late afternoon, after a day photographing the tragedy, Franklin said search and rescue had come to a halt: “They anticipated tower 7 was going to collapse. Fire and rescue gathered at a first aid center. I was like, ‘I need to go back,’ and that’s when I saw the three firemen; they were fumbling with the flag. It was shot at a distance, and it just happened.”

But did he know that he had just taken an iconic photo?

“That’s the million-dollar question,” Franklin said. “I just spoke at a Bergen County 9/11 ceremony and that’s how I started the talk. This picture did not stand out to me. Three men raising a flag paled in comparison to thousands of people dying and two buildings falling to the ground. I can’t even say this is the best picture I ever took. It is the photo with the most meaning.”

“For a brief moment, the similarity to [Joe] Rosenthal’s picture [“Raising the Flag on Iwo Jima”] flashed through my mind and I recognized the symbolism,” said Franklin, who recalled the feeling but described working with “no concept of time that day.”

After his photo was used for The Record and put on The Associated Press wire shortly after midnight, the picture, he said, “took on a life of its own.”

“The picture and the level of attention it got, for a while was unprecedented,” he said. “I still don’t lose focus on the fact that thousands of innocent people died. That was a murder scene, and people died in the most horrific way.”

The man who captured a moment of hope in a time of horror will spend the 10-year anniversary of Sept. 11 covering the ceremony at ground zero. “For journalists who were working that day, I think this is a tough time,” he said. “But all anniversaries are as important, and people need to remember what happened that day. I don’t want people to forget.”

See also, Franklin's "Witness to History" site.
description: Thomas E. Franklin says he didn't realize his photo of firefighters on Sept. 11 would become so iconic.
